epidemiology: Affects over 500 million people worldwide; incidence increasing due to obesity and sedentary lifestyles.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Start metformin → Escalate if needed based on HbA1c

epidemiology: Major cause of heart failure and stroke; prevalent in over 1 billion people with hypertension.
treatment_protocol: Control BP → Evaluate heart function → Use appropriate heart failure meds

epidemiology: Most common cause of anemia worldwide; especially common in women and children.

emergency_markers: Severe anemia with chest pain or syncope

treatment_protocol: Confirm low ferritin → Oral iron for 3–6 months → Reevaluate hemoglobin

epidemiology: Affects ~10% of adults globally; diabetes and hypertension are leading causes.
treatment_protocol: Stage CKD → Manage BP and proteinuria → Refer if GFR <30

epidemiology: Affects 5–10% of population; commonly due to H. pylori or NSAID use.

important: H. pylori test (urea breath or stool antigen)

treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Treat H. pylori → Maintain PPI if needed

epidemiology: Affects over 300 million people globally; primarily due to smoking and environmental pollutants.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Inhalers → Monitor for exacerbations → Long-term oxygen if needed

epidemiology: More common in women of childbearing age; higher prevalence in African, Asian, and Hispanic populations.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Hydroxychloroquine ± steroids → Monitor organ involvement

epidemiology: Common endocrine disorder; Graves’ disease is the leading cause in young women.
treatment_protocol: Start beta-blocker → Antithyroid drug → Consider definitive treatment

epidemiology: Annual incidence of 1 per 1,000 adults; increased risk in postoperative and immobile patients.

emergency_markers: Sudden dyspnea or chest pain (suggests PE)

treatment_protocol: Suspect based on symptoms → Confirm with ultrasound → Start anticoagulation

epidemiology: Affects 0.5–1% of population globally; female to male ratio is 3:1.
treatment_protocol: Early diagnosis → Start DMARDs → Monitor for remission or flare

epidemiology: Leading cause of infection-related death globally; affects elderly, infants, and immunocompromised.
treatment_protocol: Assess severity → Empirical antibiotics → Supportive care → Reassess in 48–72 hrs

epidemiology: Global prevalence ~3.5%; common in Asia and Sub-Saharan Africa; risk of cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose chronic infection → Monitor HBV DNA & ALT → Treat if high viral load or fibrosis

epidemiology: Affects up to 20% of adults weekly; increasing incidence with obesity and sedentary lifestyle.

timeline.symptom: Worsening after meals or lying down

emergency_markers: Severe chest pain with dysphagia or weight loss

treatment_protocol: Lifestyle → Trial of PPI → Scope if alarm symptoms or no response

epidemiology: Affects 10 million annually; highest in low/middle-income countries; transmitted via respiratory droplets.

definitive: Rifampin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol for 6 months

treatment_protocol: Diagnose via sputum + CXR → Start RIPE → Monitor for drug toxicity

epidemiology: Common metabolic disorder; major risk factor for cardiovascular disease; affects ~30% of adults.
treatment_protocol: Assess CV risk → Lifestyle change → Start statin if indicated

epidemiology: Affects ~1–2% of adults globally; more common in men and those with metabolic syndrome.

emergency_markers: Severe pain with fever (rule out septic arthritis)

treatment_protocol: Manage acute attack → Start urate-lowering therapy if recurrent

epidemiology: Common in patients with chronic hepatitis or alcohol use disorder; major cause of liver-related mortality.
treatment_protocol: Confirm etiology → Manage complications → Monitor for transplant need

epidemiology: More common in males <40 years; associated with HLA-B27 gene.

emergency_markers: Severe flare with restricted mobility or visual symptoms

treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Start NSAIDs → Consider biologics

epidemiology: Affects 200 million women worldwide; leading cause of fractures in elderly.
treatment_protocol: Confirm low BMD → Supplement → Start antiresorptive if indicated

epidemiology: 38 million people living with HIV; common in Sub-Saharan Africa; major cause of morbidity and mortality.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose → Start ART → Monitor response and complications

epidemiology: Affects ~10% of population globally; commonly associated with H. pylori infection and NSAID use.

important: H. pylori testing (urea breath test or stool antigen)

treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Start PPI → Treat H. pylori if present

epidemiology: Common electrolyte abnormality in hospitalized patients; higher incidence in elderly and patients on diuretics.
treatment_protocol: Classify type → Restrict fluids or correct → Monitor closely

epidemiology: Rare disorder; incidence ~2 per million; peak in teens and elderly; often idiopathic or drug-induced.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Supportive care → Consider transplant if severe

epidemiology: Affects ~12% of global population; more common in women; often begins in adolescence.
treatment_protocol: Identify triggers → Abortive therapy → Prophylaxis if frequent

epidemiology: Affects ~10% of global population; leading causes are diabetes and hypertension.
treatment_protocol: Stage CKD → Slow progression → Prepare for RRT if needed

epidemiology: Affects 20-150 per 100,000; more common in women of childbearing age and individuals of African or Asian descent.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Assess organ involvement → Tailor immunosuppression

epidemiology: Affects ~1% of global population; more common in females; peak onset 30–50 years.
treatment_protocol: Early DMARD initiation → Monitor response → Adjust for remission

epidemiology: Incidence 13–45 per 100,000 annually; most common causes are gallstones and alcohol.

timeline.symptom: Severe epigastric pain radiating to back

treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Supportive care → Treat underlying etiology

epidemiology: Occurs in >50 years, especially women; often associated with giant cell arteritis.
treatment_protocol: High ESR/CRP + clinical features → Start steroids → Taper gradually

epidemiology: Most common genetic disorder in Caucasians (~1 in 200); iron overload due to HFE gene mutation.
treatment_protocol: Confirm overload → Start regular phlebotomy → Monitor ferritin

epidemiology: Rare autosomal recessive disorder (~1 in 30,000); presents in childhood or early adulthood.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose → Initiate chelation → Long-term monitoring

epidemiology: Rare disorder; can be primary (AL) or secondary (AA); seen in chronic inflammatory states.
treatment_protocol: Confirm amyloid type → Treat cause → Supportive care

epidemiology: Rare (3–11 cases per million/year); usually idiopathic or due to ADAMTS13 deficiency.
treatment_protocol: Suspect clinically → Start plasma exchange immediately → Confirm ADAMTS13

epidemiology: Prevalence 10–40 per 100,000; more common in African-Americans and Northern Europeans; usually in young adults.
treatment_protocol: Confirm with biopsy → Start steroids if symptomatic → Monitor organ function

epidemiology: Uncommon (1–2 per 100,000/year); more common in females; peak onset 10–30 years.
treatment_protocol: Exclude other causes → Confirm biopsy → Start immunosuppression

epidemiology: Affects ~1 in 1,000 women over age 40; autoimmune destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose → Start UDCA → Monitor progression → Consider transplant

epidemiology: Incidence ~1 per 10,000; more common in men and associated with IBD (especially ulcerative colitis).
treatment_protocol: Diagnose via MRCP → Treat cholangitis → Consider transplant

epidemiology: Prevalence ~20 per 100,000; bimodal age distribution; autoimmune anti-ACh receptor antibodies.
treatment_protocol: Confirm with antibodies → Start pyridostigmine → Add steroids if needed

epidemiology: Affects adults >50 years; incidence ~10 per 100,000/year; progressive fibrosing interstitial lung disease.
treatment_protocol: HRCT for diagnosis → Start antifibrotics → Refer for transplant if eligible

epidemiology: Prevalence ~1–2% in older adults >50; more common in Western countries; focal increase in bone turnover.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose with ALP + imaging → Start bisphosphonates → Monitor response

epidemiology: Affects about 1% of the global population; more common in Caucasians and females.
treatment_protocol: Positive serology → Confirm by biopsy → Gluten-free diet

epidemiology: Common endocrine disorder, especially in women over 60; most cases are autoimmune (Hashimoto’s).

emergency_markers: Myxedema coma: altered mental status, hypothermia, bradycardia

treatment_protocol: High TSH + low T4 → Start levothyroxine → Titrate dose

epidemiology: Graves’ disease is the most common cause; more prevalent in women aged 20–40.

emergency_markers: Thyroid storm: fever, confusion, tachycardia, high-output failure

treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Block symptoms → Treat cause

epidemiology: Rare (1 in 10,000); autoimmune adrenalitis is most common cause in developed countries.
treatment_protocol: Confirm cortisol deficiency → Replace steroids → Monitor electrolytes

epidemiology: Rare catecholamine-secreting tumor; prevalence 0.1–0.6% in hypertensives; often discovered incidentally.
treatment_protocol: Biochemical confirmation → Localize tumor → Alpha-blockade → Surgery

epidemiology: Common acute complication of type 1 diabetes; also occurs in type 2 under stress or infection.
treatment_protocol: Fluid resuscitation → IV insulin → Monitor K+ and acidosis

epidemiology: Prevalence 1 in 200–300 in Northern Europeans; autosomal recessive mutation (HFE gene).
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Start phlebotomy → Monitor ferritin and organs

epidemiology: Affects 10–15% of adults; major causes are diabetes and hypertension.
treatment_protocol: Monitor GFR/stage → Delay progression → Plan RRT if advanced

epidemiology: Primary form more common in postmenopausal women; secondary in CKD; incidence ~1 in 1,000.

emergency_markers: Hypercalcemic crisis: altered mental status, dehydration, arrhythmia

treatment_protocol: Confirm PTH-dependent hypercalcemia → Localize adenoma → Surgery or meds

epidemiology: Myeloproliferative disorder; median age ~60; JAK2 mutation in >95% of cases.
treatment_protocol: Confirm with labs + JAK2 → Phlebotomy → Cytoreduction for high risk

epidemiology: Prevalence ~20–150 per 100,000; more common in women of childbearing age, especially African and Asian descent.
treatment_protocol: Confirm with serology → Hydroxychloroquine ± steroids → Monitor organ involvement

epidemiology: Rare; incidence 1–2 per 100,000; more common in females aged 30–50.
treatment_protocol: Identify subtype → Manage organs → Immunotherapy as needed

epidemiology: Rare idiopathic inflammatory myopathy; peaks in 40–60 years, more common in females.
treatment_protocol: Confirm with labs + biopsy → Start steroids → Add immunotherapy if needed

epidemiology: Prevalence ~1%; female:male ratio ~3:1; peak onset 30–50 years.
treatment_protocol: Early diagnosis → Start DMARDs → Escalate if inadequate control

epidemiology: Affects ~1 in 500 adults >50 years; associated with polymyalgia rheumatica.
treatment_protocol: Suspect based on symptoms → Start steroids immediately → Confirm with biopsy

epidemiology: Rare large-vessel vasculitis; mostly affects women under 40, especially of Asian descent.

emergency_markers: Severe hypertension due to renal artery stenosis

treatment_protocol: Diagnose via imaging + labs → Start steroids → Long-term immunosuppression

epidemiology: Rare vasculitis; affects both sexes, usually aged 40–60; associated with c-ANCA.
treatment_protocol: Confirm with serology/biopsy → Induction therapy → Maintenance regimen

epidemiology: Rare necrotizing vasculitis; affects both genders equally, usually in middle age.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose via biopsy/ANCA → Start immunosuppression → Long-term follow-up

epidemiology: Very rare; affects young males and older females; antibodies against GBM.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose with anti-GBM & biopsy → Start triple therapy

epidemiology: Common in people >50 years; female predominance; often associated with giant cell arteritis.
treatment_protocol: Elevated ESR/CRP → Trial of steroids → Taper slowly

epidemiology: Rare disorder; can be primary (AL), secondary (AA), or hereditary; incidence increases with age.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose via biopsy → Subtype classification → System-specific treatment

epidemiology: More common in African Americans and Northern Europeans; peaks at 20–40 years of age.
treatment_protocol: Rule out infection → Biopsy confirmation → Treat based on severity

epidemiology: Very common; affects 4–10% of adults; higher in women and elderly; autoimmune (Hashimoto) most common.
treatment_protocol: Elevated TSH → Start/review levothyroxine → Monitor TSH regularly

epidemiology: Very common electrolyte disorder; more frequent in hospitalized and elderly patients.
treatment_protocol: Assess severity → Correct slowly → Treat underlying disorder

epidemiology: Common in elderly and ICU patients; caused by water deficit more than sodium excess.
treatment_protocol: Identify cause → Gradual correction → Monitor for cerebral edema
